channel.title: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class
channel.description:
I've been working really hard trying to recreate PvP worlds. I have come across a problem, Earning Potential is apparently global. If someone loses EP, everyone loses the same amount of EP. How can I make EP an individual variable.
FIXED!! [IMG]http://i42.tinypic.com/67rrit.jpg[/img]

item.title: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“Strucker, post:19, topic:535243”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=654045.msg4381906#msg4381906 date=1383836924]
You don’t understand the meaning of static.
[/quote]Yes i do. How do you even say that, you can’t know what i do know and what i don’t, off thread.

[quote author=Docent link=topic=654045.msg4381900#msg4381900 date=1383835745]
I see, I put the EP variable in the “Settings.java”, so I should add it to the player class as a non static variable?
[/quote]add it on the fudgeing player class non static for god sake.[/quote]

Thats what I said numb nuts. I stated that at first I had it in Settings.java, I’ve moved it to Player.java

Read full topic
item.source: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class

item.title: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

If you want each instance to have control over a variable set it to non-static. If you want all instances to have no control over the variable, set it to static. It’s a fairly simple concept.

Read full topic
item.source: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class

item.title: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“DAn0194, post:22, topic:535243”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=654045.msg4381909#msg4381909 date=1383838654]
Clearly you don’t of you wouldn’t have suggested it.
[/quote]
I don’t understand why you are telling strucker he is wrong what he is saying will work.[/quote]
The only time a static variable should be used is within a constant variable, there may be a time when your design requires it, but that isn’t ideal.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7279887/what-is-use-of-a-private-static-variable-in-java

Read full topic

FYI: Avoid using static unless its a constant or part of your application design/specific instances

item.title: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:9, topic:535243”][quote author=Ambokile link=topic=654045.msg4381753#msg4381753 date=1383783819]

Also, what is up with the player name in your pic? did you like convert the name to bytes, then forget to convert back in the send message?

He’s just using player.ToString() or something of the like, rather than actually getting the player’s name. It’s getting the string representation of the player object
[/quote]

This, it is a printout of the instance of player which redirects to player.toString(), which just prints out basic information about the class unless you override the method and specify what to print out.[/quote]
That’s a rather absurd way to do it imo.

Read full topic
item.source: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class

item.title: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“Ambokile, post:7, topic:535243”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=654045.msg4381750#msg4381750 date=1383783248]
Also, what is up with the player name in your pic? did you like convert the name to bytes, then forget to convert back in the send message?
[/quote]
He’s just using player.ToString() or something of the like, rather than actually getting the player’s name. It’s getting the string representation of the player object[/quote]

This, it is a printout of the instance of player which redirects to player.toString(), which is just a string that contains basic class information such as name, package and hashcode, unless you override the method and change what the string equals.

Read full topic
item.source: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class

[/quote]
He’s just using player.ToString() or something of the like, rather than actually getting the player’s name. It’s getting the string representation of the player object[/quote]

item.source: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class

item.title: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“Ambokile, post:4, topic:535243”][quote author=DAn0194 link=topic=654045.msg4381642#msg4381642 date=1383753907]
Make the variable static.
[/quote]

No, don’t do this.

Static variables belong to the class, and so they are hold the same value across all instances of the class. Non-static variables belong to their instance of the class and therefore hold a unique value for each instance of the class (well, not entirely a unique value. Two different instances could have “number” equalling 1, but they could also have “number” as a different value for each instance).

Your EP variable needs to be in the Player or Client class, and it needs to be non-static! Define it like so:

as opposed to

http://www.pp.rhul.ac.uk/~george/PH2150/html/node48.html[/quote]
Lol oh shit he is right I got mixed up.

Read full topic
item.source: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class

item.title: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class
item.dc:creator: @Ambokile Ambokile
item.description:
@Ambokile wrote:

DAn0194:

Make the variable static.

No, don’t do this.

Static variables belong to the class, and so they are hold the same value across all instances of the class. Non-static variables belong to their instance of the class and therefore hold a unique value for each instance of the class (well, not entirely a unique value. Two different instances could have “number” equalling 1, but they could also have “number” as a different value for each instance).

Your EP variable needs to be in the Player or Client class, and it needs to be non-static! Define it like so:

as opposed to

http://www.pp.rhul.ac.uk/~george/PH2150/html/node48.html

Read full topic

item.title: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class
item.dc:creator: @JavaX JavaX
item.description:
@JavaX wrote:

I think you need to make it apart of the player instance. It should act similar to all the other variables in the player class, such as health (each player can have different health without affecting other players’ health).

Try and look at a similar way to put the EP in so that it’s unique per instance of the player class. You could also save their EP to the characters save file so it remains upon logout.

Read full topic
item.source: [FIXED]How to make a Variable specific to an instance of a class
